instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with 5v only [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Hello, I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that won't power on. No signs of liquid. Just stopped charging.

With the board out, on 3 of the ports I get 5.12v 0.37-0.39a and the 4th port (left side front) I get 5.14v but only 0.13a.

With the 3 ports I get 12.2v constant on PPBUS but 0v on the low port.
If I switch for a different dc in board, I get the same readings

I'm not sure where to start with this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with 5v only [SOLVED]
threads.message: Compare diode mode readings around <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with 5v only [SOLVED]
threads.message:
For <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>:
<CAPACITOR>C3108</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> is only 0.021v
<CAPACITOR>C3104</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_XA_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> is only 0.019v

but for <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, the same caps are around 0.453v

So <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is the problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with 5v only [SOLVED]
threads.message: UB300 & UB400 seem fine and they're similar to each other

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with 5v only [SOLVED]
threads.message: The only reason to have very low resistance on two different rails, is bad <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with 5v only [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> today and the low resistance went away, the MacBook works perfectly now.
Thank you for your help as always 2informaticos.
